It seems like the region name is not passed to the sdk. I could not find what is the right way to do this, but after reading the source code, this is what we found to make it work with a custom region:

  service_url = f"https://{self.provider.region}.iaas.cloud.ibm.com/v1" % self.provider.region 
  self.cloud_vpc.set_service_url(service_url)
That looks like a good update; I don't think it's strictly required to contact the API endpoint of the region being used, but it sure makes sense.  :)

it might be useful to check that the selected subnet is in the correct zone, otherwise if there is a mismatch, it will fail when creating the instance (`Error: the network interface's subnet is located in a different zone from the vsi`).

    subnet_zone = self.subnets[self.provider.subnet]['zone']['name']
    if subnet_zone != self.provider.zone:

Getting the exclusive-and-required behavior we want for the image-* attributes is tricky with voluptuous.  We have to do it in two steps:

  1) The schema should match the (name, username, etc) dictionary.  This includes a requirement than no more than one image-* attribute be present (but doesn't indicate that any of them are required).
  2) At least one image-* must be present, and beyond that we don't care what else is there.

The last five failures of nova-ceph-multistore were all on this patch. I still have no idea why this could happen but the numbers look too significant for me to simply ignore this.

recheck nova-ceph-multistore seems to be failing pretty often for this patch. I don't see how this could be related, but would be good if we could get it more stable or else make it n-v

> The last five failures of nova-ceph-multistore were all on this patch. I still have no idea why this could happen but the numbers look too significant for me to simply ignore this.

I have an interest in the nova-ceph-multistore job working so I was taking a look here. The N-2 and N-1 failures were caused by mysql going OOM and thus everything after that failing with mysql connection failures in the logs. I doubt that's related to this patch.

The N-0 failure looks to be a hard lockup of nova-compute, the likes of which we rarely see. It freezes mid-stream after "Creating image" and never utters another log message, not even periodics. That usually is only something like a blocking library call or something, or more often something like a disk-exhaustion sort of thing (which this isn't). After that step, I think we make some ceph calls (I see no relevant errors there) and some calls to glance (which involve the tls proxy). But, no idea why we'd succeed a thousand times and hard-freeze this time.

I'd like to recheck this maybe a couple more times to see what other data we might collect. I'll throw a -W on it for the time being.

Yeah. Let's be sure to do a few rechecks (with good results) before we merge. Given the one hang around the time where we'd be talking to glance and other weirdness I was wondering if maybe we've got a client issue? Something that causes us to get stuck occasionally loading the cert with the larger key or something...
If changing this to sha256 is causing issues we probably have bigger problems somewhere else as well. I rebased it just to make sure we aren't missing something.

Well, I dunno why a rebase might have affected this, but recent test runs seem happy. The content of the patch wasn't really relevant to the failures we were seeing anyway, so it's hard to say much about it either way.

I think we know this should be a safe thing to do, and now we have some evidence that it's not super fail-happy (at the moment at least). I'd vote for putting this in and letting it soak in the firehose at this point. I'll +2 but let someone else +W if they agree.
lgtm, let's merge, if this will cause an issue somewhere,  it would need to be addressed sooner or later anyway
I agree, thank you Dan for testing it out and chasing the errors.

kernel-rt/centos/kernel-rt.spec.message:
It would be good to avoid having a gap in the patch numbers, so that refreshing patches is easy in the future. In other words, instead of 0001 -> 0019 without 13 and 14, we should have 0001 -> 0017 only. Would it be possible to renumber the patches to achieve this?

You can do this by applying all patches except 13 and 14 to the kernel repository with "git am", and then regenerating them with

```
git format-patch -N -o .../path/to/patch_dir/ <base commit ID>..HEAD
```

This comment is applicable to the standard kernel (kernel-std) as well.

Thank you.
I don't know why you folks insist on using numbered patches in the first place.  They only serve a purpose if it's the only way used to order them.  Otherwise they are just a confusing PITA.

I had them all nicely de-numbered in the past.  Anyway, if anyone is interested I have two extremely simple scripts, one for creating an ordered patch list file from the spec file, and the other for git am'ing patches in a repo given a patch list file.  Only needed these scripts because silly build-pkgs --edit won't apply patches using git am (see https://bugs.launchpad.net/starlingx/+bug/1856897 and feel free to upvote it).  The only viable excuse for numbering patches was "well how else am I going to get them git am'ed in the right order in my working source repo, I can just use git am * and the numbering ensures the order."

But yeah, I'm not holding up this review over numbering issues, especially if we're going to move to a saner model of using git and branches as we've discussed before.

Jim, agreed, this is why we gave up on them in Yocto and WRLx. Anyway, this will go away as we move to maintaining the kernel in git and not via patches. So I am not fussy how this resolves. Since I am typically reviewing my preference is usually to see the minimal set of changes in a commit, thus my previous comment, but whatever folks who are managing these in the short term prefer using is OK.

Based on the internal discussion, let's consider the patch numbering gap to be a minor temporary issue that can be worked around until the switch to a git-based kernel source code management model. Thanks for the feedback, all.

I agree that it is not an issue for git am, but it makes the workflow worse when we need to regenerate the patches with "git format-patch". When refreshing patches, we would need to run git format-patch twice with manually determined arguments to ensure that the gap is kept.

In other words, prior to this patch, the workflow for refreshing patches is like this:

```
git am .../*.patch
git format-patch -o .../new_patch_dir/ -N @{u}..HEAD
```

However, after this patch, it will be like something this:

```
git am .../*.patch
git format-patch -o .../new_patch_dir/ -N -12 HEAD~5
git format-patch -o .../new_patch_dir/ -N -5 --start-number=14 HEAD
```

I would prefer to not have to use the second approach if possible, because it is unnecessary overhead on a valid workflow.

I should add that git and Gerrit handle renamed files gracefully, at least usually, so the code review should not be impacted a lot.

I also agree that the issue will be moot when we stop using patches.

I can go both ways on this. The approach used here makes it easier to review, the gap is not an issue for 'git am *.patch', but may be if you are using a range.

Eventually this goes away when we stop using patches.

After some further testing this may not be as important as first thought. Working this through, Neutron manages routed pods with host aggregates to identify which hosts are in which segments. When these are first (automatically) created they appear to take into account which networks a host can reach, but ignore the segment identifiers. As a result, unless Neutron code is adjusted I don't think this is strictly necessary.
I'm OOO today but will check this out ASAP (prob next week).

Further testing negates my previous comment. Neutron requires unique 'net_name's for hosts in each pod for this to operate correctly. As a result, adding 'reference_group' support here does seem useful. I've amended the commit message, comments and release note to reflect this.

Just so I can make sure I understand correctly, reference_group(s) provide the ability to further segment hosts based on some capability or difference (i.e. rack location) that cannot be done with group_binds outside of creating groups for each rack (in addition to whatever other group membership you're trying to define). If so, seems reasonable and a nice approach.
Yes, that's my understanding and the intention of the patch.

tobiko/tests/sanity/openshift/test_opens.message:
While this approach is quick and solves the requirement , 
(Only..) If you ever need more intricate control of this module , 
you could always use ansible_runner :
https://ansible-runner.readthedocs.io/en/stable/python_interface/
I implemented it like this, and it saved me time when I needed a dict to access 
the results of the ansible run:
https://github.com/rhos-infra/bzaf/blob/2ffe925db38102fa35b13c91bec95944f7580c42/bzaf/api/backends/ansible.py#L167

I tried out ansible runner and it where adding few value with far more requirements. Whild the oppion of using the ansible runner is still on the plate, I think we first have to write a tiny API in tobiko to abstrack the execution of ansible playbooks.

Looking ad the ansible-runner code I realized that there is lot of overlapping between tobiko and such framework at the time of executing ansible-playbook command. And what is not much of convenience is the way they hide (or not present in tobiko.log file) the stderr/stdout of ansible command.

It looks to me this is more intended to integrate Ansible in an asynchronous python service than into a batch process as a test case is.

While adding a complex API (with some features) by using it we loose some importan features that Tobiko has. For example tobiko knows how to reach undercloud node under any circustance and configuration without having to deal with SSH client configuration. Ansible runner is instead more suitable for running ansible from localhost (that could be or not undercloud node).

Most of the code I wrote here to run the playbook is also required by the ansible runner. On the other side the ansible runner can anso be executed as a command line tool in the same way we are using ansible-playbook command, but at the very end it is just a wrapper.

Thank you any way for pointing it out aniway.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I don't get this part. I see lots of reverts of good practice of using { and }.

This is only valid if your containers are based on bash as shell terminals, for instance official Prometheus container use a binary endpoint directly leading to braces madness on vars substitution.

There is a visual benefit to get expansion used everywhere and as it doesn't bring any pitfall we should keep it.

this is not a good practice use expansion everywhere! as the bash manual says: "The parameter name or symbol to be expanded MAY BE enclosed in  braces,..." and "The braces are REQUIRED WHEN parameter is a positional parameter with more than one digit, or when parameter is followed by a character which is not to be interpreted as part of its name."

Following on this, this is actually considered as good practice for two reasons. One was already mentioned by Fl1nt - being better for human eyes. The other reason is related and it's that they make it easier to avoid mistakes due to human miscalculating the boundary of variable name, e.g., trying to add _BLAH to something like FOO_$HELLO ends up being FOO_$HELLO_BLAH which is not correct.

zuul/zk/event_queues.py.message: How does this affect non transaction event puts? Does everything just end up with q in the name? or does sequence=True in the create() calls drop the q and replace it with a number? Mostly wondering if we'll end up with two different types of names in zk.

We'll get "q0000000000" in both cases.  We will have both for a while as an installation changes over, but the old ones should age out.  We don't rely on ZK's ordering (the events implement ordering in python) so having the two styles coexist for a while won't affect functionality.

It's just a quirk (I haven't traced it down to where exactly) that without a character after / they behave differently; but with one they behave the same.

zuul/zk/job_request_queue.py.message:
Note that the exception object comes from ZooKeeper; we get a list of the result for each operation in sequence which might be a regular object, or it might be an exception... basically the failure scenario looks like:

transaction.set('/a')
transaction.get('/b')
result = transaction.commit()
print(result) => [RollbackError, NoNodeError]

Pushing the result into postRun just to reraise the exception and then possibly catch it seems like a bad way to handle this (because its working the opposite direction to how most exceptions flow). But I can't come up with a better way to avoid needing to catch NoNodeError and handle that in this common code.

swift/container/backend.py.message: I added ShardRange.ACTIVE_STATES after this, so we can remove this and just use ShardRange.ACTIVE_STATES below now.

swift/container/sharder.py.message: we might want to modify this condition to active+/active++ just like shrinking candidates, but for now we should leave it as is (minimum change to existing behaviour)

Yeah, this is just a start. First phase I wanted to just keep everything as it is (except for Shrinking) so in essence for everything else ACTIVE has become ACTIVE_STATES. But haven't really had much time to really consider.
curious about this change - but i guess we want the root to be shardable, so maybe it makes sense?
Yeah.. I wasn't sure here either to be honest. I picked ACTIVE_PLUS incase the acceptor wouldnt be picked. This is still early days 😊

Since this is >= in a 3-replica system it'll look a lot like "num_done > 1" (i.e. 2)

Al had described the final state as ALL replicas being done, but I'm nervous about even writing down the *idea* that an "active++" state exists to mean "everyone" has done whatever - with handoffs I'm almost positive I could get all the replicas in primary locations reporting "yup, all done with everything *I* have" while there's still some db out there trying to cleave

Yeah, everything done would be awesome, but I think hard to determine. That's why I decided to go with quorum. We make other decisions on it.. and really we just want to be sure this active shard is cleaved enough that it could now be a candidate. On a 3 replica that's 2, but at least scales to bigger replica counts.

need to think more about this - but IIRC this happens once for each replica - we may want the replicas to check cleaving contexts repeatedly (in audit?) and progress the state as they can. Otherwise might all replicas execute this while they have just their own cleaving context being 'done'?

Yes! I was thinking about an audit over night. Because there is no garantee that we'd ever get see more then 1 or even a quorum, becasue they'll complete themselves and then replicated the contexts around.

Though might also add, if the shardrange is already ACTIVE then choose ACTIVE+ Because we know someones done in this case right. In otherwords don't just rely on cleave contexts. And means ACTIVE+ is a safety need that we know at least more then 1 has merged which might be good enough.

Adding this so the sharded container cannot be deleted unless all the contexts have been cleaned up. This will be done, even if there are stale contexts in audit contexts. So contexts can't magically be cleaned out if something is delayed for some reason.
There is only one usage of this now, so may not need it anymore.

As this currently stands it means we wont ever move into the CLEAVED state until we have a qaurum at the same spot. And CLEAVED_MINUS isn't in the LIST_STATES so means we'd be relying on the old shard for longer.. but should plug the hole.. maybe?

Not sure if this is the right number. Because it's context wide not just a single cleave.. but it could be a single cleave. I assume really fast ones are just a few objects so maybe the number (default 10% so shard_threshold) is big enough.

The other option is to not use a number at all and always fall back to ACTIVE_MINUS until there is a quorum. In which case the parent patch of this isn't required.

Agree, this is probably not the right number - if the whole parent only cleaved shrink_size rows then there's almost certainly a brand new shard with less than shrink_size rows. Plus, if shrink_size is set low then 'fast handoff' cleave could satisfy this condition.
doesn't this allow two 'fast handoffs' to create a quorum?

Yes it does.. this is my biggest worry. quorum is great.. unless something can reach it incorrectly.

I guess the more replicas the less likely though :shrug:

We could have a configuration:
  ALL: Where there needs to num-replicas CleavingContext dones. Although when taking handoffs into account we may need to not be a number of dones but rather only when all current primaries have cleaved. And use this to only to make progress slowly.
  QUORUM: Only when we get a quorum CleavingContexts (this patches behaviour).
  ALWAYS: Always move to ACTIVE and/or CLEAVED. Todays behaviour.

ALL - would require being able to identify the primary CleavingContexts. Oh or would we only see current primaries? because a handoff wouldn't replicate it's cleavecontext to primaries as it'll only shard to shards.

So how many fast handoffs could we expect to have? if handoffs CleaveContexts dont propergate, they can't mark things as ACTIVE (unless there the container ring has a replica count of 2 I guess), so post patch, can it only happen if there is a small primary. Would we ever get 2 of those?

deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml.message:
I was wondering why you moved setting the ceph_ansible_skip_tags fact to it's own task. As per our conversation in IRC:
 
Originally the ceph_ansible_skip_tags fact was set in the block on line 591 with the tags ceph and cephadm_adopt. By creating a separate task to set the ceph_ansible_skip_tags fact, you can set this fact regardless of how the cephadm_adopt tag is set.

Can you give me more context though on when the cephadm_adopt tag is set? Is it that you are now going to be calling the resultant playbook with tags=cephadm_adopt and you don't want this fact set?

Not really, let me try to explain better, and I should probably improve the COMMITMSG to explain the purpose of this change.

When the command::

openstack overcloud external-upgrade run --stack overcloud --tags cephadm_adopt

is run, in /var/lib/mistral/<UUID>/ the ansible playbook is exported and then executed, and the execution flow follows the tasks where the "cephadm_adopt" tag is present.
Before this patch, the skip tag list was set twice, the first time in the "external_upgrades_tasks" (L770), but later, the override of the same fact was performed in the "external_deploy_tasks" [1], because the cephadm_adopt tag is present at block level.
I still need to execute all the tasks of that block because the ceph-ansible context is set there, but I need to skip the set_fact for the variables already set in the previous branch (external_upgrades_tasks).
This is the reason I moved both extra_vars and skip_tags on a different task, where the cephadm_adopt tag is not present in external_deploy_step but only in the exterrnal_upgrades_tasks branch. 


[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/
Ditto my comment above on line 575.
see my reply on your L575 comment.
I understand why lines 777-785 are for external_upgrade_tasks as the adopt playbook needs them to set the ceph_ansible_extra_vars fact.

When the upgrade run is performed, two set of tasks are executed in the following order:

1. the external_upgrade_tasks tasks 
2. the external_deploy_steps_tasks

If foo is set in #1, it shouldn't be set again in #2, otherwise an override is performed.
This is the reason of L575, where both extra_vars facts and skip tag list are moved away from the block and added (same step) as separated task, but w/ no "cephadm_adopt" tag.

One of the possible values is th LayoutState.branch_cache_min_ltimes which is a regular dict (and since it's stored in ZK, would be difficult to change to a defaultdict).  All things considered, I think this may be the best solution.

This was super unexpected defaultdict behavior for me. Basically bar.get('foo', -1) will return -1 rather than the defaultdict default value. However, you don't get a KeyError if you do bar['foo'] and that returns the default. I wonder if we should reraise here instead of setting this to -1 to ensure we are using defaultdicts. But this should be fine as is.

have we abandoned comma separated values for a reason ?

Spaces require quotes.  It's easy to forget, creating potentially strange results.

The syntax for these lines is governed by sources.list (https://manpages.debian.org/bullseye/apt/sources.list.5.en.html), it already includes commas in option values, eg:

deb [ arch=amd64,armel ] http://deb.debian.org/debian bullseye main

Suggest we keep spaces here.

          for request in self.inState(BuildRequest.REQUESTED):

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: this should be more specifically scoped.  Why does commenting this out "apply the default taint"?

Hi John.

Currently, the default taint is being removed from master nodes on:
- kubernetes.pp (https://opendev.org/starlingx/stx-puppet/src/branch/master/puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/manifests/kubernetes.pp#L339), 
- kubeadm.yaml.erb (https://opendev.org/starlingx/ansible-playbooks/src/branch/master/playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/common/files/kubeadm.yaml.erb#L10)

Now, we need to restore the default taint for Standard systems. So in both cases we need to check the system_type, and do not delete the taint if it's Standard.

The last one was added as a bugfix for bug 1928722 (https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/ansible-playbooks/+/791831). So we have to add the "taints: []" line on kubeadm.yaml only for AIO systems.

That's why I'm commenting it out for standard.
 
I've tested this change (also with https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/stx-puppet/+/810117) on a fresh install on standard, and the taint is applied correctly.

I don't know if commenting this line is the best way, I need your feedback on this.

Thanks!

I'd rather we be explicit here and show what taints we're applying to the system.

If you have time you can move kubeadm.yaml.erb to a jinja2 template. The erb template is a holdover from when puppet needed to use the template as well.

Hi David
Thanks for bring this up. About moving to jinja2 template, we will be working while 22.06 release to address this with an specific epic. Due we are rushing to get things done for the whole Taint/toleration epic while current sprint, we will consider your comment as part of 22.06 release. Please let us know any issue.
Thanks for the feedback.
Gustavo

As of now you can configure stores two ways;

1. Old way
[glance_store]

default_backend = fast

[fast]
<rbd_specific_options>

[slow]
<file_store_specific_options>

[Default]

[glance_store]
default_backend = fast

[fast]
<rbd_specific_options>

swift/container/sharder.py.message: after upgrade there will be existing contexts with no rows_cleaved value. How do we want to treat those? We might need to make the default value None or -1 so we can differentiate a legacy context from a new context with zero rows cleaved.

I don't think we'd want this reset here: the CleavingContext is reset when the DB max_row has changed during cleaving (so some extra rows unexpectedly crept in to the retiring DB). We then cleave again but only the rows from last_cleave_to_row, so rows_cleaved should continue to increment rather that revert to zero.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Would be nice if the packages were alphabetized

I usually don't agree to the "can we just get this in I will follow up with other fixes to address the problems". Just been burnt too many times by this, usually the right answer is do the fixes first then accept this new change in its final form.

That being said, these 6 or so additions are a drop in the bucket in this case and will allow you to continue with build system changes that are timely. So I agree let's get this merged.

Please follow through on the story to sort out the various lst files *and* include cleanup (assigned to the right person, does not have to be you). For instance the base-bullseye.lst contains entries like 'tasksel' which is of questionable use in STX images, and I suspect there are more.

These are to support building docker images within the build system. Shouldn't these be added as Dockerfile pkgs installs to the builder? This change will include these in the StarlingX ISO, which we don't want. Am I missing something?

> This change will include these in the StarlingX ISO
Will it? I thought we only include packages from stx-std.lst file.

Thanks for the explanation.

>> All the packages in the default standard ISO image = base-bullseye.lst + distro/os-std.lst + distro/stx-std.lst

My question is: is every package listed in base-bullseye.lst installed in the ISO? Or just the ones pulled in as dependencies via os-std.lst & stx-std.lst ??

OK thanks.

I think we will need to improve this. This file already contain packages that don't belong in the ISO (most -dev packages, gcc).

@Bob Church, @Mark Asselstine: I propose we create a separate story to separate download lists from ISO lists.

In the meanwhile I'd like to merge this patch anyway. I do need these extra packages to build container apps.

Though not clear about the 'container apps' you want to create, is that ok for you to add the packages into "tools/debian-mirror-tools/config/debian/containers/os-std.lst"?  then all the required packages to be installed into the 'container app' are from the original base-bullseye.lst + containers/os-std.lst?  Would you need a new LAT yaml file for this 'container app' to define some attributes, e.g. image name.

No, I don't think this would work.

Bob's objection is for adding _any_ packages to _any_ lists files, that are not needed in the ISO, because the lists files are used to populate the ISO. With that in mind, there's no place to specify a package that is (effectively) needed at build time, but not at runtime. I think this needs to be improved.

We don't need LAT yaml files for container apps -- they are just docker images, they just need access to apt/deb repositories (deb-local-binary, deb-local-build).

Every package listed in base-bullseye.lst will be installed in the ISO. You can check the 'packages' field in '/localdisk/deploy/lat.yaml' in builder, every package listed in base-bullseye.lst will be added into this field and installed by LAT.

According with the original design, there are three types of package lists in "tools/debian-mirror-tools//config/debian/" directory:

common/base-bullseye.lst: The minimal binary packages list to build the basic bullseye OS without any starlingX packages.

Since we are not clear about the criteria to distinguishing these Debian packages into the STX's layers like 'distro','flock', it assumes the default building layer is "distro"(), and we just added below lists and hope them to be filled during the developing: 
distro/os-std.lst:  All the extra binary packages which the STX packages depends on in distro layer
distro/stx-std.lst: All the STX packages

All the packages in the above three lists will be put into the starlingX ISO image(They will be added into the /localdisk/deploy/lat.yaml first then handled by LAT during 'build-image')
In other words,
All the packages in the default standard ISO image = base-bullseye.lst + distro/os-std.lst + distro/stx-std.lst

In addition, any package that needs to be installed into one of the docker containers(builder, pkgbuilder, repomgr, lat) should edit the dockerfile directly, e.g.:
tools/stx/dockerfiles/{stx-aptly.Dockerfile, stx-builder.Dockerfile , stx-lat-tool.Dockerfile, stx-pkgbuilder.Dockerfile}.

But it seems the packages you want are not belong to the above cases?  Maybe need new package lists or some modifications?  Anyhow the current 'base-bullseye.lst' has deviated from the original design and become bigger and bigger, I think it should be splited.

I created a task for list file separation + cleanup:

Story: 2008846
Task: 44770
Thanks Davlet. I'm good with merging this for now and cleaning up later.

validations_libs/ansible.py.message: This should happen earlier in the process as we already check the validations existence in the run_validations method of the ValidationActions class.

something is done wrong here, got this:

validations_libs/constants.py.message: What about the gather_facts key some validations have in their playbook?
The 'gather_facts' key is optional and validations can work without it. So the schema does not require its presence.
What about the categories and products keys?

only the validations in validations-common will have to be patched asap. Otherwise, validations from TV are ok in master and the backport is on his way into wallaby [1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-validations/+/807996

Nope, we already had this discussion and it is written in the validation metadata evolution specification in a red note:

<< The products and the categories keys will have to be present in the validation playbooks but as for the groups, these keys might be set to an empty list. >>

The custom Ansible-lint you've improved went into this direction too!

PS: Categories and products will only hit master and wallaby.

I have to point out, that right now, numerous validation playbooks are not compliant with this specification. The playbook validator patch, if set up so that it demands these keys, would inevitably break things. Unless the playbooks were changed first.

The schema would have to be delayed, or merged now and updated later otherwise.

Unlike 'groups' which are used in all validations to some degree and have a pre-defined list of accepted values, the categories and products are relatively recent addition and are explicitly optional.

Therefor the schema does not require them.

Some validations are calling tasks from a role playbook like this way:

     tasks:
       - include_role:
           name: role_name
           tasks_from: playbook.yaml

Which means they won't pass the schema validation!
A good point, this will require adjustment.

validations_libs/utils.py.message: In addition to the fact that this check should be done earlier, we should be strongly inspired by the way our ansible-lint rule works here. By that, I mean, collect all the anomalies found and present them to the user in one shot! And not raising an exception at the first issue.
Reasonable change, it would simplify the code a bit as well.
Do we really need a strict mode? if we have a known and official structure we can already check above?
Eh, need is a relative term, but in this case I tend to agree. The schema is getting a bit too strict already.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
If we can change the commit message, then I'm ok with giving it a +2.

+Harald,

If a user uses composable roles, such that Controller gets named ControllerFoo, then would you require their yaml file which is passed to `openstack overcloud node provision` (described in link below) to use those exact same role names?

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/provisioning/baremetal_provision.html#baremetal-provision-configuration

Thanks,
  John
Thanks Francesco for the discussion about this patch. I'm just taking note of what the root cause seems to be for now. I'll review more later.
Thanks Francesco. I'm curious what Harald thinks about this case.

Perhaps we should abandon this patch?

This patch introduces "fuzzy role mapping" for deployed ceph. E.g. ControllerNFS is close enough to Controller so let's assume the user meant ControllerNFS in their "declarative YAML format specifies what roles will be deployed and the desired baremetal nodes to assign to those roles" as defined in:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/provisioning/baremetal_provision.html

There are a number of problems here:

- The user is _supposed_ to use an exact and "declarative YAML format [which] specifies what roles will be deployed and the desired baremetal nodes to assign to those roles" and by using this fuzzy role mapping we might introduce unintended bugs or behavior which is difficult to predict.

- Even if deployed ceph works with the fuzzy role mapping we know the overcloud deployment will fail since the ansible inventory won't support the fuzzy role mapping either.

For these reasons I propose abandonment.

tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/.message:
We could say this line (250) is the root cause of the issue since this:

  ControllerStorageNfs + HostnameFormat 

is not in the output deployed metal file [1]. However, we could say it was user error since it was designed such that the topology input file which is passed to metalsmith (which then generates the output that line 250 is parsing) would have the exact role name. I.e. this happened because the input metal file didn't use a name for the first line which mapped the role. Consider ControllerStorageNfs vs Controller.

---
- name: ControllerStorageNfs
  count: 3
  instances:
    - hostname: oc0-ceph-0
      name: oc0-ceph-0
    - hostname: oc0-ceph-1
      name: oc0-ceph-1
    - hostname: oc0-ceph-2
      name: oc0-ceph-2
  defaults:
    networks:
      - network: ctlplane
        vif: true
      ....

Instead, I believe the first line of the above was just Controller. 

I think that if you compose roles, then you need to use those role names as input for metalsmith:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/provisioning/baremetal_provision.html#baremetal-provision-configuration

However... 

I see Francesco has made the parsing more flexible or forgiving to the user by using a regex.

*.Controller.*

This will be more forgiving if the user does this and a testing scenario [2] has been added to cover when we will just do the match.

It's possible the user could compose a role with unrelated names, e.g. what if it's just called Foo. In that case it will fall though this net, but we shouldn't cover that case as we'd need to provide the user some extra mapping interface.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/molecule/default/mock/mock_deployed_metal.yaml#L4

[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/831523/4/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/molecule/default/mock/mock_overcloud_roles_composable.yaml

I tried to dig more into this, and I guess that this part is rendered according to the defined role name [1].
This means that your approach of strictly matching {{ role.name }} + HostnameFormat was right.
This patch in theory isn't supposed to break that pattern, but we also need to check the templates are properly generated and fail if something doesn't match the defined pattern, which means working more on the patch.
I'm not sure a "ceph" module is the right place where we want to see the failure, but the user shouldn't be supposed to reach the Ceph step with "wrong" templates. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/wallaby/overcloud.j2.yaml#L257

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: what is the reason behind this "and", you want to check the port type is virtual and it was virtual before too? So, if it is now virtual and before it was not, there is no need to bind it?
Ohh, I see, I think I now understand it! Thanks for the awesome explanation! We only want to react to it once the chassis is added (to add the binding).

I'll document it. The VIP port, before the IP address is assigned to another one as allowed address pair, has type "". When a new virtual parent is assigned, the type "virtual" is assigned too. If all virtual parents are removed, the type is removed too.

We need to detect when the new and old types are "virtual"

https://paste.opendev.org/show/bAuJO1E747Glx6wTol5N/

Sorry Luis, I don't get you here. Let me explain the logic implemented. Ping me in IRC if something is not clear.

There are three main events here (but we only need two in this feature):
1) When the allowed address pair is updated. The VIP "Port_Binding" register is updated. The "virtual-parents" list and the "type" are updated at the same time. But we don't care about it.

2) The other way around, when all allowed address pairs are removed. The "virtual-parents" key is removed from "options" and "type" is unset (actually "" is written). We use this event to remove any Neutron DB portbinding "host" field (NOTE: actually the portbinding register cannot be updated, we remove it and create a new one with the updated host, but this is irrelevant here).

3) After (1), when "virtual-parents" have at least one LSP, if traffic from/to this VIP address is detected, the "Port_Binding" register is updated with the "chassis" hosting the port receiving/sending this traffic. We use this event to update the Neutron DB portbinding "host" field.

Thanks for the explanation!

I still have a doubt (most probably me missing something again). When the IP is assigned as allowed address pair (and therefore moving from "" to "virtual", don't we want to also update the port binding? And the same for the other way around, we would like to remove the binding details in case the port goes from virtual to "" (though perhaps that is automatically done by other event noticing the update on the port binding for "" type.
this is not always about binding the virtual port, right? perhaps better to name it something like update_virtual_port_binding

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Not quite sure I understand here.. before the first unlocked, the mount point is not in the fstab. the mount command here is not going to mount the device. but the command is not going to fail as failure is ignored. The next command will ensure the mount point present in fstab, and try to remount, would that command pass and the mount succeed?

Only /scratch is affected by this behavior, I'll try to explain below:

For /scratch, before the first unlock it is already on the fstab, but when the manifest runs it gets unmounted at some point and when it gets to the mount resource it will try to remount (remount -o) and will fail with error code 32, as it is not mounted, and this is what we want to address with the exec mount command before the mount resource.

For other filesystems, before the first unlock they will not be in the fstab, so the mount command (in exec) will not be able to mount it, but the following mount resource will add them to fstab and mount them (no remounting here).

When class barbican::api is called, we can update the gunicorn-config.
~ lines 490 in barbican api.pp remove the check:
    # Debian is using UWSGI, not gunicorn
    if $::os_package_type != 'debian' {
      file_line { 'Modify bind_port in gunicorn-config.py':
        path  => '/etc/barbican/gunicorn-config.py',
        line  => "bind = '${bind_host}:${bind_port}'",
        match => '.*bind = .*',
        tag   => 'modify-bind-port',
      }
    }

The problem with this is that puppet-module-barbican is a binary package we include in the iso. I think it's better to do this in stx openstack barbican.pp so to avoid building puppet-module-barbican from source and patching it.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/te.message:
Let's think about this in relation to this merged patch:

 https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/825416

If push_destination is true in the container prepare yaml, then the container would already have been downloaded to the undercloud when container prepare was run before deploying ceph. So at that point the undercloud registry has a copy of the image.

Then because of this, when ceph is deployed and passed the same container prepare yaml, the overcloud is configured to treat the undercloud as a container registry.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/825416/5/tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_ceph.py

But did tripleo_cephadm_container_ns get set to undercloud so that the declaration above refers to the correct thing? We know ContainerCephDaemonImage has the correct value from the output of the container image prepare. I just want to make sure we're not overriding it with the wrong value.

Note how the image_map is updated here:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/825416/5/tripleoclient/utils.py#3181

Might be worth it to try a couple of scenarios to be sure tripleo_cephadm_container_ns is set properly emperically.

even if you wait for the port to become active
it is not safe for any test to used this this allow to know if it can proceed to connect to the guest.

there can be quite a long delay in some cases between the port becoming active in neutron and the ip becoming reachable on the instance. there can be an even longer delay in the instnace ssh deamon starting up.

functions tests that use this function allow to wait
for and ip to become actvies then to break if you run tempest against ironic nodes and it you are using qemu second level guest i can also be problematic in the gate.

as such i would suggest that approch is a much better solution then waiting for the port to become active to adre bug 1728600
